Comment: With compulsory voting in Australia the number of eligible voters enrolled to vote is usually around 97% and the voter turnout for elections is usually around 90-95% of eligible voters  Australia's electoral commission is fiercely independent, it does not work to cull voters from the rolls, it works to get as many people as possible voting. If you move to a new electorate in Australia and forget to enroll at your new address you don't get purged from the electoral roll, you just vote in whatever electorate you are enrolled to vote in and get a reminder to update your enrollment

Comment: This election was won by an ALP government which campaigned well and projected both stability and good governance.  The LNP opposition campaigned poorly and was bereft of policies. Its leader Peter Dutton has the personality of a crypt keeper and an appearance to match. He began his campaign with hints of Trump-lite and their policy development was lazy and ill-conceived.  Then came the turbo-charged chaos of Trump tariffs and all the rest. Trying to humiliate Zelensky in the WH and threatening annexations among many other things made the prospect of Australia changing government highly unlikely.  That the Albanese ALP government achieved a second term increase to its majority is history making. Trump did not cause the ALP victory. The uncertainties and anxieties he has inflicted on the world however certainly must be considered as one of the factors in it achieving a history making increased majority.

Comment: We don't all really vote in our Speedos, despite the publicity ad.  I voted in the Adelaide CBD today. The polling booth I went to was close to a major retail precinct and was very busy, had a lot of interstate people, as well as other people who were still 'local' but didn't live in the electorate.  We have compulsory voting in Australia; and have had forever as far as I know. We also don't vote for a President; we elect local members, and the party that wins a majority chooses the Prime Minister. In practice this is the leader of their party, but many people think they're voting for either the incumbent Prime Minister or the Leader of the Opposition.  As a political junkie, the thing that disappointed me was that most of the people queued up had no idea which electorate they lived in. The electoral officials were quizzing people in the queues where they lived. I was slightly sad that I was one of the few who knew which electorate I was enrolled in (Adelaide, both the suburb and the electorate). But it didn't stop them from giving the conservative Liberal/National Party Coalition (our Conservatives) a big finger.  I'll take the win.
Author: CommanderSleer

Comment: A bit of context here from an Australian: The leader of the opposition party (LNP) tied himself heavily to MAGA style anti-woke politics, to the point where he was colloquially known as Temu Trump. Comment: Nope. The only restrictions for voting once you rock up to the polling booth are:  You must be an enrolled Voter (Enrollment is mandatory and covers like 98% of the eligible population)  You must NOT have voted in the election already  You must NOT be attempting to advertise for a party, nor be attempting to otherwise influence other voters within the bounds of the venue (or within 6m of the door)  Making sure voting is as easy and accessible as possible is a key part of our democracy. Everyone should have a say, so we do our best to ensure that's the case.

A donkey vote is when they just number the boxes in the order they appear on the page, so it by default becomes a vote for the person whose name appears first. Itâ€™s still a valid vote and still has to be counted even though they clearly put no effort into it, which is why it matters to politicians whose name gets listed first on each ballot paper.   The classic drawings of dicks, writing in names, or just writing â€œfuck youâ€ in the boxes are â€œinformalâ€ votes - they get thrown away and donâ€™t count towards anything. Thereâ€™s actually not that many of them, way fewer than I wouldâ€™ve expected. The AEC website has the statistics for basically all of time available which is pretty neat.  Anyway, thatâ€™s your â€œwell actuallyâ€ from this election nerd for the day, sorry about that I just think itâ€™s all really neat and I like sharing.

Comment: I really wish Canada had that system of voting. I tend to support the Greens or the NDP (bit further than centre-left, but still firmly establishment), but I often have to pick who *might* win in my riding.  There's also some ridings where, say there's a three-way race between a complete asshole and two not-so-terrible people. The two not-so-terrible people win the majority of votes (say, 32% + 33%), but because nobody's talking to another about who to vote for and the data is flawed or absent, the asshole wins the riding because he had the largest number of votes (35%). Looking at you, North Island-Powell River.

Comment: We have safeguards you do not.  Compulsory voting, meaning 95% turnout in an average election. Ranked choice/preferential voting, meaning there is no way for me to waste my vote, and neither I nor anyone else am limited to just two bad choices. An independent electoral commission administering the whole deal; voter suppression, Elonâ€™s campaign financing shenanigans and gerrymandering are all a lot harder to pull off. The possibility to sack/replace a PM halfway through his term with little fuss - we donâ€™t rely on impeachment, we can do it in a week if we lose confidence in the bastard. There was a period a few years back where it happened repeatedly, we changed PMs when we changed the smoke alarm batteries.  It could happen here, youâ€™re right. Thatâ€™s always a possibility that has to be guarded against. But a LOT of stuff would have to change about what we do and why we do it before our elections look like yours.
Author: AlamutJones
